segment.source: This topic describes the use of contact geometry for touch targeting and provides best practices for targeting in Windows Runtime apps.
segment.target: This topic describes the use of contact geometry for touch targeting and provides best practices for targeting in Windows Runtime apps.

segment.source: Targeting
segment.target: Targeting

segment.source: Guidelines for targeting
segment.target: Guidelines for targeting

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Touch targeting in Windows uses the full contact area of each finger that is detected by a touch digitizer.
segment.target: Touch targeting in Windows uses the full contact area of each finger that is detected by a touch digitizer.

segment.source: The larger, more complex set of input data reported by the digitizer is used to increase precision when determining the user's intended (or most likely) target.
segment.target: The larger, more complex set of input data reported by the digitizer is used to increase precision when determining the user's intended (or most likely) target.

segment.source: Important APIs
segment.target: Important APIs

segment.source: Windows.UI.Core
segment.target: Windows.UI.Core

segment.source: Windows.UI.Input
segment.target: Windows.UI.Input

segment.source: Windows.UI.Xaml.Input
segment.target: Windows.UI.Xaml.Input

segment.source: This topic describes the use of contact geometry for touch targeting and provides best practices for targeting in UWP apps.
segment.target: This topic describes the use of contact geometry for touch targeting and provides best practices for targeting in UWP apps.

segment.source: Measurements and scaling
segment.target: Measurements and scaling

segment.source: To remain consistent across different screen sizes and pixel densities, all target sizes are represented in physical units (millimeters).
segment.target: To remain consistent across different screen sizes and pixel densities, all target sizes are represented in physical units (millimeters).

segment.source: Physical units can be converted to pixels by using the following equation:
segment.target: Physical units can be converted to pixels by using the following equation:

segment.source: Pixels = Pixel Density × Measurement
segment.target: Pixels = Pixel Density × Measurement

segment.source: The following example uses this formula to calculate the pixel size of a 9 mm target on a 135 pixel per inch (PPI) display at a 1x scaling plateau:
segment.target: The following example uses this formula to calculate the pixel size of a 9 mm target on a 135 pixel per inch (PPI) display at a 1x scaling plateau:

segment.source: Pixels = 135 PPI × 9 mm
segment.target: Pixels = 135 PPI × 9 mm

segment.source: Pixels = 135 PPI × (0.03937 inches per mm × 9 mm)
segment.target: Pixels = 135 PPI × (0.03937 inches per mm × 9 mm)

segment.source: Pixels = 135 PPI × 0.35433 inches
segment.target: Pixels = 135 PPI × 0.35433 inches

segment.source: Pixels = 48 pixels
segment.target: Pixels = 48 pixels

segment.source: This result must be adjusted according to each scaling plateau defined by the system.
segment.target: This result must be adjusted according to each scaling plateau defined by the system.

segment.source: Thresholds
segment.target: Thresholds

segment.source: Distance and time thresholds may be used to determine the outcome of an interaction.
segment.target: Distance and time thresholds may be used to determine the outcome of an interaction.

segment.source: For example, when a touch-down is detected, a tap is registered if the object is dragged less than 2.7 mm from the touch-down point and the touch is lifted within 0.1 second or less of the touch-down.
segment.target: For example, when a touch-down is detected, a tap is registered if the object is dragged less than 2.7 mm from the touch-down point and the touch is lifted within 0.1 second or less of the touch-down.

segment.source: Moving the finger beyond this 2.7 mm threshold results in the object being dragged and either selected or moved (for more information, see Guidelines for cross-slide).
segment.target: Moving the finger beyond this 2.7 mm threshold results in the object being dragged and either selected or moved (for more information, see Guidelines for cross-slide).

segment.source: Depending on your app, holding the finger down for longer than 0.1 second may cause the system to perform a self-revealing interaction (for more information, see Guidelines for visual feedback).
segment.target: Depending on your app, holding the finger down for longer than 0.1 second may cause the system to perform a self-revealing interaction (for more information, see Guidelines for visual feedback).

segment.source: Target sizes
segment.target: Target sizes

segment.source: In general, set your touch target size to 9 mm square or greater (48x48 pixels on a 135 PPI display at a 1.0x scaling plateau).
segment.target: In general, set your touch target size to 9 mm square or greater (48x48 pixels on a 135 PPI display at a 1.0x scaling plateau).

segment.source: Avoid using touch targets that are less than 7 mm square.
segment.target: Avoid using touch targets that are less than 7 mm square.

segment.source: The following diagram shows how target size is typically a combination of a visual target, actual target size, and any padding between the actual target and other potential targets.
segment.target: The following diagram shows how target size is typically a combination of a visual target, actual target size, and any padding between the actual target and other potential targets.

segment.source: diagram showing the recommended sizes for the visual target, actual target, and padding.
segment.target: diagram showing the recommended sizes for the visual target, actual target, and padding.

segment.source: The following table lists the minimum and recommended sizes for the components of a touch target.
segment.target: The following table lists the minimum and recommended sizes for the components of a touch target.

segment.source: Target component
segment.target: Target component

segment.source: Minimum size
segment.target: Minimum size

segment.source: Recommended size
segment.target: Recommended size

segment.source: Padding
segment.target: Padding

segment.source: 2 mm
segment.target: 2 mm

segment.source: Not applicable.
segment.target: Not applicable.

segment.source: Visual target size
segment.target: Visual target size

segment.source: 60% of actual size
segment.target: 60% of actual size

segment.source: 90-100% of actual size
segment.target: 90-100% of actual size

segment.source: Most users won't realize a visual target is touchable if it's less than 4.2 mm square (60% of the recommended minimum target size of 7 mm).
segment.target: Most users won't realize a visual target is touchable if it's less than 4.2 mm square (60% of the recommended minimum target size of 7 mm).

segment.source: Actual target size
segment.target: Actual target size

segment.source: 7 mm square
segment.target: 7 mm square

segment.source: Greater than or equal to 9 mm square (48 x 48 px @ 1x)
segment.target: Greater than or equal to 9 mm square (48 x 48 px @ 1x)

segment.source: Total target size
segment.target: Total target size

segment.source: 11 x 11 mm (approximately 60 px: three 20-px grid units @ 1x)
segment.target: 11 x 11 mm (approximately 60 px: three 20-px grid units @ 1x)

segment.source: This implies that the size of the actual target and padding combined should be larger than their respective minimums.
segment.target: This implies that the size of the actual target and padding combined should be larger than their respective minimums.

segment.source: These target size recommendations can be adjusted as required by your particular scenario.
segment.target: These target size recommendations can be adjusted as required by your particular scenario.

segment.source: Some of the considerations that went into these recommendations include:
segment.target: Some of the considerations that went into these recommendations include:

segment.source: Frequency of Touches: Consider making targets that are repeatedly or frequently pressed larger than the minimum size.
segment.target: Frequency of Touches: Consider making targets that are repeatedly or frequently pressed larger than the minimum size.

segment.source: Error Consequence: Targets that have severe consequences if touched in error should have greater padding and be placed further from the edge of the content area.
segment.target: Error Consequence: Targets that have severe consequences if touched in error should have greater padding and be placed further from the edge of the content area.

segment.source: This is especially true for targets that are touched frequently.
segment.target: This is especially true for targets that are touched frequently.

segment.source: Position in the content area
segment.target: Position in the content area

segment.source: Form factor and screen size
segment.target: Form factor and screen size

segment.target: Finger posture

segment.source: Touch visualizations
segment.target: Touch visualizations

segment.source: Hardware and touch digitizers
segment.target: Hardware and touch digitizers

segment.source: Targeting assistance
segment.target: Targeting assistance

segment.source: Windows provides targeting assistance to support scenarios where the minimum size or padding recommendations presented here are not applicable; for example, hyperlinks on a webpage, calendar controls, drop down lists and combo boxes, or text selection.
segment.target: Windows provides targeting assistance to support scenarios where the minimum size or padding recommendations presented here are not applicable; for example, hyperlinks on a webpage, calendar controls, drop down lists and combo boxes, or text selection.

segment.source: These targeting platform improvements and user interface behaviors work together with visual feedback (disambiguation UI) to improve user accuracy and confidence.
segment.target: These targeting platform improvements and user interface behaviors work together with visual feedback (disambiguation UI) to improve user accuracy and confidence.

segment.source: For more information, see Guidelines for visual feedback.
segment.target: For more information, see Guidelines for visual feedback.

segment.source: If a touchable element must be smaller than the recommended minimum target size, the following techniques can be used to minimize the targeting issues that result.
segment.target: If a touchable element must be smaller than the recommended minimum target size, the following techniques can be used to minimize the targeting issues that result.

segment.source: Tethering
segment.target: Tethering

segment.source: Tethering is a visual cue (a connector from a contact point to the bounding rectangle of an object) used to indicate to a user that they are connected to, and interacting with, an object even though the input contact isn't directly in contact with the object.
segment.target: Tethering is a visual cue (a connector from a contact point to the bounding rectangle of an object) used to indicate to a user that they are connected to, and interacting with, an object even though the input contact isn't directly in contact with the object.

segment.source: This can occur when:
segment.target: This can occur when:

segment.source: A touch contact was first detected within some proximity threshold to an object and this object was identified as the most likely target of the contact.
segment.target: A touch contact was first detected within some proximity threshold to an object and this object was identified as the most likely target of the contact.

segment.source: A touch contact was moved off an object but the contact is still within a proximity threshold.
segment.target: A touch contact was moved off an object but the contact is still within a proximity threshold.

segment.source: This feature is not exposed to Windows Store app using JavaScript developers.
segment.target: This feature is not exposed to Windows Store app using JavaScript developers.

segment.source: Scrubbing
segment.target: Scrubbing

segment.source: Scrubbing means to touch anywhere within a field of targets and slide to select the desired target without lifting the finger until it is over the desired target.
segment.target: Scrubbing means to touch anywhere within a field of targets and slide to select the desired target without lifting the finger until it is over the desired target.

segment.source: This is also referred to as "take-off activation", where the object that is activated is the one that was last touched when the finger was lifted from the screen.
segment.target: This is also referred to as "take-off activation", where the object that is activated is the one that was last touched when the finger was lifted from the screen.

segment.source: Use the following guidelines when you design scrubbing interactions:
segment.target: Use the following guidelines when you design scrubbing interactions:

segment.source: Scrubbing is used in conjunction with disambiguation UI.
segment.target: Scrubbing is used in conjunction with disambiguation UI.

segment.source: For more information, see Guidelines for visual feedback.
segment.target: For more information, see Guidelines for visual feedback.

segment.source: The recommended minimum size for a scrubbing touch target is 20 px (3.75 mm @ 1x size).
segment.target: The recommended minimum size for a scrubbing touch target is 20 px (3.75 mm @ 1x size).

segment.source: Scrubbing takes precedence when performed on a pannable surface, such as a webpage.
segment.target: Scrubbing takes precedence when performed on a pannable surface, such as a webpage.

segment.source: Scrubbing targets should be close together.
segment.target: Scrubbing targets should be close together.

segment.source: An action is canceled when the user drags a finger off a scrubbing target.
segment.target: An action is canceled when the user drags a finger off a scrubbing target.

segment.source: Tethering to a scrubbing target is specified if the actions performed by the target are non-destructive, such as switching between dates on a calendar.
segment.target: Tethering to a scrubbing target is specified if the actions performed by the target are non-destructive, such as switching between dates on a calendar.

segment.source: Tethering is specified in a single direction, horizontally or vertically.
segment.target: Tethering is specified in a single direction, horizontally or vertically.
